messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., "Paolo Perrotta" <pperrotta@i...> wrote:
> > setUp and tear down are used for each testcase, but it would be
enough
> > to run them once. There is an example in the FAQ but I couldn't
find
> > out, how to get it running.
>
> The rationale of the system is that each test must be independent
> of others. That's why setUp() and tearDown() are called for each
> single test case. Why do you want to setUp and tearDown your text
> fixture only once?
>
> Anyway, if you really want to do this you can do either of these
> two ugly things:
>
> - Write your own testSetUp() method as the first test method in the
> class and testTearDown() as the last test method in the class.
> Pretty ugly, but it should work. I didn't try it myself, so I'm not
> 100% sure it will.

if i'm not mistaken, you should never depend on test methods in a
class being executed in any particular order. so you could never
guarantee that a testSetUp() method would be called first, nor a
testTearDown() method called last (short of altering the framework).

try writing a subclass of TestSetup, whose setUp() and tearDown()
perform setup/teardown of test fixture once for the Test object the
TestSetup decorates. e.g.:

public class DatabaseSetup extends TestSetup
{
public DatabaseSetup(Test test)
{
super(test);
}

protected void setUp() throws Exception
{
// create tables, add rows, etc.
}

protected void tearDown() throws Exception
{
// drop tables
}
}

then use your TestSetup in a test class's suite() method:

public class MyTest extends TestCase
{
public static Test suite()
{
return new DatabaseSetup(new TestSuite(MyTest.class));
}
}

or, if it's test fixture like objects that your test class need to
access directly, make them attributes of the test class, and
initialize them in the test class's constructor rather than in
setUp().

--p
